"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Summarized chunk:
Congress finds that Jackie Roosevelt Robinson, born on January 31, 1919, in Cairo, Georgia, was a talented athlete who excelled in multiple sports at the University of California Los Angeles. In 1947, he made history by becoming the first black player in Major League Baseball when he signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers. Jackie Robinson's signing with Major League Baseball in 1947 was a significant moment in American sports history. He won the National League's Rookie of the Year Award in his first season and was later voted the league's Most Valuable Player in 1949. In 1962, Robinson was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame, and his achievements extended beyond athletics to have a profound influence on civil and human rights in America. Although Jackie Robinson's achievements began with athletics, they had a profound influence on civil and human rights in America. His signing as the first black player in Major League Baseball preceded significant events in desegregation, civil rights marches, and a historic Supreme Court ruling. The American public viewed Robinson as a person of exceptional fortitude, integrity, and athletic ability. Jackie Robinson quickly became one of the most popular figures in America, ahead of President Harry Truman, General Dwight Eisenhower, and Bob Hope in a national poll. He later became vice president of Chock Full O' Nuts and co-founded the Freedom National Bank of Harlem. Robinson's influence extended beyond athletics, impacting civil and human rights in America. Jackie Robinson's legacy includes co-founding the Freedom National Bank of Harlem and influencing political leaders. He also worked with various organizations to improve the lives of Americans. The Jackie Robinson Foundation continues his principles by providing educational opportunities for children from low-income families. The Jackie Robinson Foundation continues his legacy by providing educational opportunities for children of low-income families, influenced by his personal achievements in civil rights advancement. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Jackie Robinson's family in recognition of his contributions to the nation. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze to cover costs. The medals are considered national medals. Authorization of appropriations is granted. The medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. An amount not to exceed $30,000 is authorized to pay for the medal, with proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. The Congress passed a bill calling for a national day to recognize Jackie Robinson's accomplishments, with the President issuing a proclamation for its observance. The Congress passed a bill to award a congressional gold medal posthumously to Jackie Robinson for his contributions to the Nation and proposed a national day in his honor.
